item.title: Container Security - Linux Capabilities and Secure Compute Profiles
item.description:
Container Security - Linux Capabilities and Secure Compute Profiles

In this post we are going to see two security mechanisms used in Linux Containers in order to provide a security layer for our workloads.

We will see how Linux Capabilities and Secure Compute Profiles can be used for limiting the attack surface for our containers.

The first part of the blog post will be an introduction to Linux Capabilities and Secure Compute Profiles, second part will show how these technologies work through the use of demos.

item.title: Containers under the Hood
item.description:
Containers are Linux

You probably already heard this expression, in today’s post we are going to desmitify container technologies by decomposing them part by part and describing which Linux technologies make containers possible.

We can describe a container as an isolated process running on a host. In order to isolate the process the container runtimes leverage Linux kernel technologies such as: namespaces, chroots, cgroups, etc. plus security layers like SELinux.
